David Saff wrote:
> 
> 
> On 2/19/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@... 
> <mailto:jbrains762%40gmail.com>> wrote:
>  > Perhaps I don't want separate tools, but a way to separate the tests
>  > into two categories: essential and coverage. The essential tests are the
>  > ones that drove my design decisions, while the coverage tests are the
>  > ones that I added to protect against future refactorings.
> 
> That restatement is interesting. I've thought in the past that I'd
> like at least three different organizational schemes for my tests:
> 
> 1) By class tested
> 2) By functionality tested
> 3) By order of creation*
> 
> You bring out possibly yet another:
> 
> 4) By intent
> 
> Perhaps 3 and 4 are similar. I've thought in the past it should be
> possible to do all of this by thinking hard about how I lay out my
> tests, but I now think that, at least, 3 and 4 lead to a different
> organization than 1 and 2. Do you think that JUnit could help with
> this, or would the first step be in an IDE?

I could imagine annotating tests with the information /in theory/, but I 
couldn't imagine stopping to bother to do it while test-driving. As I 
wrote in another message, this idea begins to feel like a teaching tool 
to me, rather than a technique for professional practice.
